all_summaries: DualPM introduces a novel dual-point map representation for monocular 3D shape and pose reconstruction of deformable objects, combining canonical and posed point maps to enable pose estimation via deformation fields. The method extends traditional point maps to handle amodal reconstruction with layered representations and achieves state-of-the-art results on 3D Fauna and unseen quadruped categories, outperforming existing methods in terms of accuracy and generalization.

DualPM introduces a novel dual-point map representation for monocular 3D shape and pose reconstruction of deformable objects, combining canonical and posed point maps to enable deformation field recovery and amodal reconstruction. The method predicts two point maps: one in canonical space and one in posed camera space, allowing for pose estimation through their difference. Amodal point maps are achieved via layered representations, capturing self-occluded points. The approach achieves state-of-the-art results on quadruped reconstruction, outperforming existing methods with minimal synthetic data and showing robustness to out-of-distribution inputs. Key findings include the effectiveness of dual PMs in capturing deformation fields and their application in skeleton fitting and motion transfer, as well as the success of the layered amodal representation in handling occlusions.
